review.title: Build Electronic Arabic Lexicon
review.abstract: There are many known Arabic lexicons organized on different ways, each of them has a different number of Arabic words according to its organization way. This paper has used mathematical relations to count a number of Arabic words, which proofs the number of Arabic words presented by Al Farahidy. The paper also presents new way to build an electronic Arabic lexicon by using a hash function that converts each word (as input) to correspond a unique integer number (as output), these integer numbers will be used as an index to a lexicon entry.

metadata.title: Build Electronic Arabic Lexicon

sections.text: This paper uses mathematical relationships to count a number of Arabic words, which is the number of Arabic words presented by Al Farahidy. It also presents a new way to build an electronic Arabic lexicon using a hash function that converts each word (as input) into a unique integer number (as output), which is used as an index for a lexicon. Keywords: Arabic lexicon, hash function, Al Farahidy, dictionary and search Engine.Received October 6, 2008; accepted May 17, 2009

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Al Khalil bin Ahmed Al Farahidy (died in A.D. 175) was the priority in the creation of the first Arabic lexicon. Since this great scientist was a man with a creative mathematical sense, which he used in all the specialization fields he worked on, this great wise scientist spared no effort in his attempt to create a lexicon that could be used to systematize and restrict the language. Al Farahidy used a mathematical method to collect and systematize linguistic parts, a method by which he got his hands on his goal, and no one took precedence in it. Al Farahidy noticed that the Arabic language consisted of (28) letters, all reproduced in vocal cords, with the exception of (alhamza)) "(which is made of glottis; therefore, he determined that no words and letters would emerge from alhamza, and organized them into a fixed vocabulary. In accordance with this order (syllables), the syllables were no longer limited to the syllables between two or five letters, with no more than five syllables.

sections.heading: 1.1. The Steps of Al Farahidy System in Al-Ein Book
sections.text: Al Khalil invented a new system for organizing dictionaries based on their places of articulation, the dictionary was not ordered alphabetically, but by phonetics, following the pattern of pronunciation of the Arabic alphabet from the deepest letter of the throat to the last letter pronounced by the lips. (Al Khalil gives this system a basis for his work in organizing his new lexicon, naming each letter as a book, so he begins with alhamza, since it is produced by the deepest letter and not by the vocal cords or the mouth. (Al Khalil gives this system a basis for his work in organizing his new lexicon, and names each letter as a book, so he begins with alhamza (lexicon), since it is produced by the vocal cords or the mouth. The second step was the search for all Arabic words limited between the two and five syllables, and he collected them accordingly (Al Khalil collects the target language for the third word).

sections.heading: 1.2. Lexicon Schools
sections.text: Dr. Hussein Nassar has compiled the following classification for Arabic lexicographies, which is divided into four types according to their methods.

sections.heading: 1.2.1. The First School
sections.text: It is also known as the al-Ein School, based on Al-Ein Book by Al Khalil, for its primacy in the Arabic lexicography world and its uniqueness in the method of collecting Arabic vocabulary, and this school has the following dictionaries: • Al-Ein Book by Al Khalil bin Ahmed Al Farahidy (died A.D. 175). • Al Bariaa Book by abi Ali Al Qali (died A.D. 356). • Al Tahzeeb by abi Mansour Al Azhari (died A.D. 370). • Al Muheet by Al Saheb bin Abad (died A.D. 385). • Al Muhkam by ibin Sayidah (died A.D. 458).

sections.heading: 1.2.2. The Second School
sections.text: It is known as Al Jamhara, and it followed the permutation system established by Al Farahidy in his book Al Ein, in addition to its pursuit of the alphabetical order in the organization of words, and it has the following dictionaries: • Al Jamhara book by abi Bakr Mohammed bin Duraid (died 321 AD) • Al Maqayis book by Ahmed bin Faris (died 395 AD) • Al Mujmal book by Ahmed bin Faris.

sections.heading: 1.2.3. The Third School
sections.text: It is known as the Al-Sihah School. This school was based on the (section and chapter) system, in which the last letter is a chapter and the first letter a section, and has the following dictionaries: • Tajulughah and Sihah Al Arabia by abi Nasar Ismail bin Hammed Al Jauhri (died around 400 AD) • Al Abab Al Zakhir Wal Lubab Al Fakhir by Al Hassan bin M. Al Sagani (died 650 AD) • Lisan Al Arab by ibin Mandour (died 711 AD) • Al Qamos Al Muheet by Al Fairouz Abadi (died 817 AD) • Al Tiraz Alau'l wal Al Kanaz Fema Alaih Lught Al Arab Al Mua'l by ibin Ma'ssoum Al Madani (died 1120 AD) • Tajullarous by M. Murtubada Al Zaidi (died 205).

sections.heading: 1.2.4. The Fourth School
sections.text: It is called the Al-Assas School. It uses the most common and simplest method of alphabetical order, in which words from the first letter to the last letter of the word are arranged according to the main letters with the exception of the auxiliary letters: • Assas Al Balaghah by Jar Allah Mahmoud Al Zamkhashari (died 438 AD). • Al Misbah Al Munir by Al Fayoumi (died 760 AD). • The entire written lexicon of modernity such as Muheet Al Muheet by Butras Al Bustani, Aqrab Al Mawared fi Fasih Al Arabia and Al Shawared by Saed Al Khouri Al Sharnoubi and the other modern encyclopedias.

sections.heading: 2. Hash Table
sections.text: A hash table works by using a hash function to transform the key into a hash table, a number that is used as an index in an array to find the desired location ("bucket") where the values should be. Normally, the number is converted to the index by taking a module, or sometimes bitmasking is used where the array size is a strength of two. The optimal hash function for any given use of a hash table can vary widely, but depending on the nature of the key. Typical operations on a hash table include inserting, deleting, and looking up (although some hash tables are precalculated so that no insertions or deletions are made, only looking up on a live system.) These operations are all performed in amortized constant time, making maintaining and accessing a huge hash table very efficient.

sections.heading: 3. Propose Algorithm
sections.text: Dictionaries are gradually gaining importance as computer technology advances, and great achievements have been made in areas such as natural language processing, speech recognition and other AI applications, most of which require the availability of a dictionary that can be maintained and retrieved in a very efficient manner. Dictionaries are also needed in traditional applications such as spell-checking and database management. Different types of Arabs are severely affected by the inability to find character-to-character matches between search terms and variant matches. In this paper, we present new ways to build an electronic Arabic lexicon that relies on building a hash table in which a word is used as a key to generate a corresponding integer index, which can be achieved by using one-to-one and a mathematical relationship.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: This paper represents a mathematical method to count a number of words that have proven the Al Farahidy theory. Our technique allows direct access to any word in the lexicon (by counting and matching index) instead of a sequential search for word letters, one letter at a time. This method can be applied to any dictionary with any language. By using relation 2, each word generates a unique number in which there are no collisions, meaning that any location in the hash table can be used. The proposed hash function dose does not need to take a module or bit masking to convert the number into the index. Typical operations in a hash table include insertion; deletion and lookup are done on a live system. The proposed algorithm uses arrays with integer keys or indexes, and then the time searched for (linear search) may be faster. Although words (letters) are equivalent in time, but they can be converted to average in time.
